title: Research
text:
The research of the Quantum Optimization Research Group focuses on the development of advanced optimization algorithms for computationally challenging decision-making problems. Our work is motivated by the growing need for scalable and reliable solution methods for problem classes that arise in engineering design, control, finance, and large-scale systems optimization.
A central theme of our research is the investigation of hybrid quantum–classical computational frameworks, where emerging quantum resources are integrated into well-established classical optimization methods in a principled and theoretically grounded manner.

title: Research
section: Core Problem Class: Mixed-Integer Semidefinite Programming
text:
Core Problem Class: Mixed-Integer Semidefinite Programming
A major focus of the group is Mixed-Integer Semidefinite Programming (MISDP). MISDP problems combine:

Discrete decision variables

Continuous semidefinite constraints

Nonlinear and nonconvex feasible regions

These problems are known to be NP-hard and represent a significant computational bottleneck for existing optimization solvers. Despite their difficulty, MISDP models naturally arise in many real-world applications, including robust control, portfolio optimization, structural design, and systems engineering.
Our research aims to develop algorithmic frameworks that address the intrinsic complexity of MISDP while preserving solution quality and theoretical guarantees.

title: Research
text:
Methodological Framework
The group adopts a decomposition-based approach to tackle MISDP problems. Our methodological toolbox includes:

Semidefinite programming relaxations

Cutting-plane and outer-approximation methods

Branch-and-bound and branch-and-cut frameworks

Problem-specific reformulations and relaxations

These techniques allow large and complex optimization problems to be decomposed into more tractable subproblems, enabling systematic exploration of the solution space.

title: Research
text:
Quantum–Classical Integration
A distinctive aspect of our research is the integration of quantum computational subroutines into classical optimization frameworks. Rather than replacing classical solvers, we investigate how quantum algorithms can be used to accelerate or enhance specific computational components, such as:

Solving structured subproblems

Improving relaxation quality

Enhancing branching or cut-generation strategies

This hybrid perspective ensures that quantum resources are used where they are most effective, while classical optimization methods provide robustness, scalability, and interpretability.

title: Research
text:
Expected Contributions
Our research contributes to both theory and practice by:

Developing novel hybrid quantum–classical optimization algorithms

Advancing the algorithmic understanding of MISDP

Providing rigorous computational benchmarks and performance analyses

Establishing principled guidelines for integrating quantum methods into classical solvers

Through these contributions, the group aims to bridge the gap between emerging quantum technologies and practical large-scale optimization.

title: About
text:
The Quantum Optimization Research Group is based in the Department of Industrial Engineering at Bilkent University. The group conducts research at the intersection of optimization theory, computational methods, and emerging quantum technologies.
Our work is driven by fundamental questions in mathematical optimization and decision science, with a particular emphasis on developing algorithmic frameworks that are both theoretically sound and computationally effective.

title: About
text:
Mission
The mission of the group is to advance the state of the art in optimization by:

Developing rigorous and scalable optimization algorithms

Bridging classical optimization methods with emerging quantum computational paradigms

Training students in mathematically grounded, algorithm-oriented research

Contributing to open, reproducible, and high-impact scientific research

We aim to produce research that is relevant both to the academic community and to real-world decision-making problems.

title: About
text:
Research Philosophy
The group follows a methodology-driven research philosophy. Rather than treating quantum computing as a standalone solution, we investigate how quantum resources can be meaningfully integrated into classical optimization frameworks.
Our research emphasizes: - Mathematical rigor and theoretical guarantees
- Careful algorithm design and decomposition
- Transparent computational benchmarking
- Practical relevance and scalability
This philosophy ensures that proposed methods are robust, interpretable, and suitable for real-world applications.

title: About
text:
Collaboration and Environment
The Quantum Optimization Research Group maintains an open and collaborative research environment. We actively collaborate with researchers from different disciplines, including:

Industrial Engineering

Mathematics

Computer Science

Systems and Control Engineering

The group also participates in national and international research projects and welcomes collaboration with academic and industrial partners.

title: About
text:
Location and Affiliation
The group is affiliated with Bilkent University, one of the leading research universities in Türkiye. Bilkent provides a strong interdisciplinary research environment and access to a vibrant academic community.
Research activities are conducted within the Department of Industrial Engineering, benefiting from close interaction with faculty and students across departments.

Overview
The Quantum Optimization Research Group focuses on the development of hybrid quantum classical optimization algorithms for challenging problems arising in mathematical optimization and decision science. Our work lies at the intersection of quantum computing, optimization theory, and computational methods.

title: Welcome to Quantum Optimization Research Group
text:
Research Focus
Our primary research direction is the design and analysis of algorithms for Mixed Integer Semidefinite Programming and related problem classes. These problems are computationally demanding and arise in a wide range of applications, including control, finance, and engineering design.
We investigate how quantum resources, when integrated with classical optimization frameworks, can improve performance in terms of solution quality, scalability, and computational efficiency.

title: Welcome to Quantum Optimization Research Group

Methodological Approach
Our research emphasizes: - Hybrid quantum classical algorithm design
- Semidefinite programming and cutting-plane methods
- Branch and bound frameworks for mixed-integer problems
- Computational benchmarking and performance evaluation
